review.title: MORSE: Semantic-ally Drive-n MORpheme SEgment-er
review.abstract: We present in this paper a novel framework for morpheme segmentation which uses the morpho-syntactic regularities preserved by word representations, in addition to orthographic features, to segment words into morphemes. This framework is the first to consider vocabulary-wide syntactico-semantic information for this task. We also analyze the deficiencies of available benchmarking datasets and introduce our own dataset that was created on the basis of compositionality. We validate our algorithm across datasets and present state-of-the-art results.

sections.heading: 3 System
sections.text: The main limitation of previous frameworks based solely on orthographic characteristics is the resulting over-segmentation. As an example, MDLbased frameworks segment "sing" to "s-ing" due to the high frequency of morphemes: "s" and "ing." Our framework combines semantic affinity with orthographic affinity to eliminate such an error. For the example mentioned, MORSE confirms morphemes such as "s" and "ing" from an orthographic perspective, but devalues the relationship between "s" and "sing" from a local and vocabulary-wide semantic perspective. Therefore, MORSE segments "jump" as "jump-ing" and does not perform segmentations on "sing." To bring semantic understanding into this relationship, we rely on word representations (Mikolov et al, 2013a; Pennington et al, 2014).

sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: We conduct a variety of experiments to evaluate the performance of MORSE and compare it with previous work. First, performance is evaluated based on the task of morpheme segmentation and against the most commonly used morpheme segmentator: Morfessor 2.0. We evaluate performance in three languages of different morphological levels: English, Turkish, Finnish, with Finnish being the richest in morphology and English the poorest. Second, we highlight the inadequacies of benchmarking gold records for this task and describe a new data set we are creating to address the inadequacy. Third, we compare MORSE against morphologist using a number of words that should not be segmented from a semantic perspective, although they appear orthographically segmentable (such as "freshman"). In all of our experiments, we report on precision and recall (and corresponding F1 values) with positions of morphems that should be considered positive (since 2011).

sections.heading: 4.1 Setup
sections.text: Both systems, Morfessor and MORSE, were trained on the same monolingual corpus: Wikipedia2 (as of September 20, 2016) to control the factors within the experiment. For each language considered, the corresponding Wikipedia dump was pre-processed with an available Code3. We use Word2Vec (Mikolov2https: / / dumps.wikimedia.org 3https: / / github.com / bwbaugh / wikipedia-extractoret al., 2013a) to train word representations of 300 dimensions based on a size 5 context window.

For the purposes of our experiments, all systems use the development data set as a test data set, and the training data set is used to adjust the hyperparameters of MORSE.

sections.heading: 4.4 Handling Compositionality
sections.text: We have hypothesized that following the MDL principle (like Morfessor) leads to over-segmentation, especially when the meaning of the word does not follow the meaning of its morphemes. Examples of this are words such as "red head," "duck face," "as always," "whatever." A subset of these words is defined by linguists as exocentric connections (Bauer, 2008). MORSE does not suffer from this problem due to its use of a semantic model. We use a collection of 100 English words that appear to be segmentable but actually are not (example: "however"). Such a collection will demonstrate the ability of a system to distinguish frequent letter sequences from the semantic contribution of that sequence of letters in a word. sections.heading: 5 Results
sections.text: We compare MORSE with Morfessor and place the performance alongside the latest published results.

sections.heading: 5.1 Morpho Challenge Dataset
sections.text: As shown in Table 3, MORSE performs better in English and Turkish than Mofessor and worse in Finnish. Considering English first, the use of MORSE instead of Morfessor resulted in a 6% absolute increase in F1 values. This supports our claim that semantic cues are needed in morpheme segmentation and also confirms the method used in this paper. Since English is a less systematic language in terms of the orthographic structure of words, semantic cues are more important, and therefore a system based on semantic cues is expected to perform better; indeed it does. Similarly, MORSE performs better in Turkish with an absolute 7% lead in F1 rating.

sections.heading: 5.1.1 Discussion
sections.text: We suspect that the richness of morphology in Finnish has led to a sub-optimal performance of MORSE. This is because the richness of morphology leads to a rarity of vocabulary, which leads directly to: (1) deterioration in the quality of word representations (2) Increased vocabulary size exacerbates the problem of limited vocabulary (remember MORSE, which was limited to a vocabulary of 1M). In a language with productive morphology, the limitation of its vocabulary leads to a lower likelihood of finding morphologically related word pairs, which negatively affects MORSE's level of education, which relies on the availability of such pairs. In order to recognize the suffix "ly" from the word "merry," MORSE also has to come across "merry." Getting over "merry" is now a less likely event due to its high rarity.

Using MC data (which does not adhere to the composition principle) to tune MORSE on SD17 (which adheres to the composition principle) is not optimal. Thus, we evaluate MORSE on SD17 with 5-fold cross validation, where 80% of the data set is used to tune and 20% is used to evaluate. Knowing the basis of the construction of SD17 and the fundamental weaknesses in MC datasets, we attribute the performance increase to the lack of compositionality in MC datasets.

sections.heading: 5.3 Handling Compositionality
sections.text: We compare the performance of MORSE and Morfessor against a series of words that consist of morphemes that do not constitute the meaning of the word. As all boundaries in this data set are negative, we only give the number of segments generated to evaluate both systems (where MORSE is matched to SD17). The more segments a system generates, the worse its performance. We find that MORSE generates 7 false morphemes, while Morfessor generates 43 false morphemes. This demonstrates the robustness of MORSE in the face of such examples through its semantic knowledge and confirms our claim that Morfessor over-segments such examples.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we have introduced MORSE, a first-ever morpheme segmentator that investigates the semantic structure at this scale (local and vocabulary-wide), demonstrating its superiority over state-of-the-art algorithms that use intrinsic evaluation in a variety of languages, identifying the weaknesses in current benchmarking datasets, and presenting a new dataset that is free of these weaknesses. Given a relative increase in performance that achieves 24% absolute increase over morfessor, this work demonstrates the importance of semantic cues and the validation of a new state-of-the-art morphem segmentator. For future work, we plan to address the limitations of MORSE: minimal oversight, greedy conclusions, and condensive orthographic models. In addition, we plan to optimize the training phase in the interest of broader adoption by the community.
